prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for dumping my gf after her unannounced backpacking trip
Ok so this happened maybe three days ago, but first some context.

Me and my (now ex) girlfriend of 3 years lived in a 2 bedroom apartment which I pay for by myself, as I make enough money to afford it and I didn’t want to trouble her by pressing her with a bill for a place that is a tiny bit out of her price range, instead we use a meter and pay the bill through my account, with her compensating her  spend.
 
We also have always been big on trust since both of us have been cheated on in previous relationships, and didn’t want to go through that again in this one.

The fact that I pay solely this apartment is important as it allows her to spend her money on things like more expensive gifts and the occasional excursion for us (which of course I pay in part for). Also the fact that we are big on trust means we tell eachother A lot about our lives and future plans.

Anyways, she was always a fan of these trips abroad and loved travelling, and for the most part our trips were always fun. However, about three days ago she announced that she had bought tickets for a solo backpacking trip across South America which she was going to go on on Friday, and that she had been planning this for months.

First I asked if I could come, to which she said no because she would be “discovering herself” on this trip, and when I asked why hadn’t she told me she said because I wouldn’t have allowed (or at the very least not wanted) her to go, especially alone.  (Which is mostly true)

Well an argument ensued and at some point I finally put my foot down, it went something like this: 

Gf: “why can’t I just go explore the world and live life to its fullest”

Me: “you can, without me or the security of my home, pack your bags and get out”

I believe it was the right thing to do as she didn’t pay for the apartment anyways, and so didn’t have any right to demand to stay, plus I was willing to give her money for a hotel for a week, which she refused.

That night she went to her parents home an hour away and my phone was blown up with people calling me a controlling asshole and the like, my question is am I really an asshole for this?

TLDR: girlfriend popped a surprise solo trip on me 5 days before she left, saying she wanted to go alone and had been planning it for months, I kicked her out my house. 


"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking whether the author (AITA) is in the wrong for breaking up with his girlfriend after she went on a solo backpacking trip without telling him. 

First, the context: They've been in a 3-year relationship. The author pays for the apartment, and the girlfriend compensates him for her portion. They both value trust, having been cheated on before. The girlfriend planned a solo trip, which the author didn't know about until 5 days before departure. He refused to come with her because she said he wouldn't support it. Then he told her to leave the apartment since she didn't pay for it, leading to the breakup.

Now, considering their living situation. The author pays for the apartment, and the girlfriend covers her part. So, technically, she's a guest in his home, right? If she's not paying rent, maybe he has the right to ask her to leave if they're no longer together. But wait, they were in a relationship, so it's a shared living arrangement. Even if she's not paying, it's expected that both partners have a say in major decisions. 

The key point is the surprise trip. She planned it for months but didn't tell him. That's a big decision affecting their shared life. The author felt it was a breach of trust or communication. But maybe she didn't think he'd support it, so she kept it a secret. However, in a relationship, major life decisions usually require discussion. 

His reaction was to kick her out. That's extreme. Even though he pays for the apartment, their relationship was supposed to be based on trust. By asking her to leave after an argument, he might be overreacting. Also, the fact that he was willing to pay for a hotel but she refused shows a lack of compromise. 

But he's the one who set up the living situation where he covers the rent. If she wasn't paying, perhaps his stance is that if she wants to leave the relationship, she should leave the house. However, the way he handled it—threatening to make her leave during an argument—could be seen as harsh. Breaking up and immediately asking for her to move out might be too abrupt. 

Also, the fact that others called him a controlling asshole is a red flag. Even if he's right about her not paying for the apartment, the method of handling the situation could be problematic. Maybe a more mature approach would have been to talk about the trip, set boundaries, or negotiate instead of using the breakup as a means to enforce his terms.

In terms of right and wrong, the girlfriend didn't inform him about a significant trip, which could be a breach of communication. But the author could have addressed it through discussion rather than an ultimatum. His solution was immediate and harsh, which might make him the asshole despite the initial issue. So, the answer is A (he's in the wrong) because his reaction was disproportionate and maybe controlling, even if there were valid concerns.
